title: Used in Chris Ware's Acme Novelty Library, could be baskerville or times style fonts
content:
I am searching for some information on Chris Ware's book Acme Novelty Library for a dissertation. Those photos came from fake old style newspaper pages.

I choose serif in the classification, but I am also searching for the sans-serif font, use to highlight some words.  
For the serif I think this is very close to the baskerville font, but some details are different.

And sorry for the photographies quality, it's an old digital device... :s  
Sorry if my english is too bad.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054739im_/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC06305_6185.JPG)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054739im_/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC06304_4377.JPG)

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054739im_/http:/typophile.com/files/DSC06167_5380.JPG)

Font: 

 Century Schoolbook, Benton Sans Bold 

Solved By: 

 [osamu](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054739/http:/typophile.com/user/215937 "View user profile.")
author: palexa

comments.content: You could try [Benton Sans Bold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054739/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontbureau/benton-sans/bold/) for the sans-serif, and for the serif, take a look at [Century Schoolbook](http://web.archive.org/web/20150422054739/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/monotype-century-schoolbook/). The Monotype version (linked) is probably the best match from what I can tell, though other foundries (Adobe, Bitstream, ITC) have renditions also worth checking.
